revision.text:
{{About|a company|general discussion of this technology and other solar roadway companies|Smart highway}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox company |name = Solar Roadways Inc |type = Startup |logo = File:Solar Roadways logo.png |foundation = {{Start date|2006}} |founder = {{unbulleted list|Scott Brusaw |Julie Brusaw}} |location = 721 Pine Street,
[[Sandpoint, Idaho]] 83864,
United States {{cite web|publisher=Solar Roadways |title= About|url=http://solarroadways.com/about.shtml}} |homepage = [http://www.solarroadways.com/ solarroadways.com] }} '''Solar Roadways Incorporated''' is an American company based in [[Sandpoint, Idaho]] aiming to develop [[solar power]]ed road panels to form a [[smart highway]]. Their proof-of-concept technology combines a transparent driving surface with underlying solar cells, electronics and sensors to act as a solar array with programmable capability. The road panels are to be made from recycled materials and incorporate photovoltaic cells.{{cite web |url= http://singularityhub.com/2014/05/22/following-the-solar-brick-road-to-clean-energy-and-smart-roadways/ |title= Following the Solar Brick Road |first= Cameron |last= Scott |date= May 22, 2014 |publisher= [[Singularity University]] |work= [[SingularityHUB]] }} The project has received criticism in regards to its feasibility and its efficiency compared to traditional solar panel installations. ==History== [[File:Solar Roadway Parking Lot Prototype.jpg|thumb|Solar Roadway panel prototypes]] The company was founded in 2006 by Scott and Julie Brusaw, with Scott as President and CEO. They envisioned replacing asphalt surfaces with structurally-engineered solar panels capable of withstanding vehicular traffic. The proposed system would require the development of strong, transparent, and self-cleaning glass with the necessary traction and impact-resistance properties at competitive cost.{{cite web |url= http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/driving-on-glass-solar-roads/ |title= Driving on Glass Solar Roads |work= Scientific American |date= October 6, 2009 |accessdate= February 24, 2015 }} In 2009, Solar Roadways received a $100,000 [[Small Business Innovation Research]] (SBIR) grant from the United States [[Department of Transportation]] (USDOT) for Phase I to determine the feasibility of the proposed project.{{cite web |title= Solar Roadways: Phase I Grant |url= http://www.sbir.gov/sbirsearch/detail/355952 |publisher= Small Business Innovation Research }} In 2011, Solar Roadways received $750,000 SBIR grant from the DOT for Phase II to develop and build a solar parking lot;{{cite web |title= Solar Roadways: Phase II Grant |url= http://www.sbir.gov/sbirsearch/detail/362311 |publisher= Small Business Innovation Research }} from this, they built a {{convert|12|by|36|ft|m|adj=on}} parking lot covered with hexagonal glass-covered solar panels sitting on top of a concrete base, heated to prevent snow and ice accumulation, with [[LED]]s to illuminate road lines and display messages. According to the Brusaws, the panels can sustain a {{convert|250,000|lb|kg|abbr=on}} load.{{cite web |first= Keith |last= Barry |url= https://www.wired.com/2014/05/solar-road/ |title= This Parking Lot Is Paved with Solar Panels |work= [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |date= May 8, 2014 |accessdate= May 24, 2014}} In April 2014, the company started a [[crowdfunding]] drive at [[Indiegogo]] to raise money so they could get the product into production. The campaign raised 2.2 million dollars and became Indiegogo’s most popular campaign ever in terms of the number of backers it attracted.{{cite web|url=https://www.transportation.gov/fastlane/new-pavement-system-supported-solar-panels|title=New Pavement System... Supported by Solar Panels?|date=December 14, 2015|publisher=}}{{cite news |url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffbercovici/2014/06/03/the-centuries-old-technology-behind-solar-roadways-indiegogos-most-popular-campaign-ever/ |title= The Centuries-Old Technology Behind Solar Roadways, Indiegogo's Most Popular Campaign Ever | work= [[Forbes]] |date= June 3, 2014 }} The success was attributed in part to a [[Twitter|tweet]] made by actor [[George Takei]], due to his more than 8 million followers.{{cite news |url= http://www.csmonitor.com/Environment/Latest-News-Wires/2014/0531/Star-Trek-George-Takei-tweet-boosts-Solar-Roadways |title= Star Trek: George Takei tweet boosts Solar Roadways |agency=Associated Press |work=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |first= Scott |last= Maben |date= May 31, 2014 |accessdate= June 1, 2014}}{{cite news |url= https://www.economist.com/blogs/schumpeter/2014/06/crowdfunding-solar-roadways |title= On the not so sunny side of the street |work= [[The Economist]] |date= June 5, 2014 }} One of the Brusaws’ videos went [[viral video|viral]], with over 20 million views as of November 2015. In December 2015, the USDOT announced that it had awarded Solar Roadways a Phase IIB SBIR contract to further their research.{{cite web |url=https://www.transportation.gov/fastlane/new-pavement-system-supported-solar-panels |title=New Pavement System... Supported by Solar Panels? |publisher=US Department of Transportation |author=Michael Trentacoste |date=December 14, 2015 |accessdate=August 22, 2016}} In 2016 they were given an additional $750,000.00 {{cite web|url=https://www.sbir.gov/sbirsearch/detail/355949|title=Solar Roadways - SBIR.gov|publisher=}} The first public installation was in Jeff Jones Town Square in Sandpoint, Idaho. It opened to the public on September 30, 2016. As a pilot install it is for walkways only.{{cite web |url=http://www.boiseweekly.com/boise/sandpoint-will-light-up-solar-roads-this-friday/Content?oid=3899013 |title=Sandpoint Will Light Up Solar Roads This Friday |work=Boise Weekly |author=George Prentice |date=September 28, 2016 |accessdate=September 29, 2016}} This installation consists of 30 Solar Roadways SR3 panels covering an area of roughly {{convert|150|sqft|m2}}. The cost of this installation was roughly $60,000 with the majority of the money coming from a grant from the Idaho Department of Commerce ($47,134), and a $10,000 grant from the Sandpoint Urban Renewal Agency.{{cite web|title=City Council Minutes 7/20/2016|url=http://www.cityofsandpoint.com/your-government/city-council-minutes|website=Sandpoint, ID: City Council Minutes|accessdate=23 October 2016}} A webcam was installed to broadcast a view of the installation.{{cite web | url = http://www.cityofsandpoint.com/visiting-sandpoint/solar-roadways | title = World’s first ever public installation of Solar Roadways! | website = City of Sandpoint | accessdate = 1 November 2016 }} The 30 tiles in Sandpoint generate power which is fed into the electricity meter at Jeff Jones Town Square. ==Criticism== In 2014, Jonathan Levine, a professor of urban planning at the University of Michigan, expressed doubt regarding the political feasibility of the project on a national scale. He suggested, however, that a single town might be able to deploy the concept in a limited test case such as a parking lot.{{cite news |url= http://www.popularmechanics.com/technology/infrastructure/a10730/we-could-build-a-solar-powered-roadway-but-will-we-16879565/ |title= We Could Build a Solar Powered Roadway. But Will We? |work= Popular Mechanics |date= June 11, 2014 |accessdate= February 24, 2015}} Journalist David Biello, writing in ''[[Scientific American]]'', noted the difficulties of the project in dealing with material limitations, particularly in its choice of making the surface of the panels from glass, which "must be tempered, self-cleaning, and capable of transmitting light to the PV below under trying conditions, among other characteristics—a type of glass that does not yet exist."{{cite web | url=https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/hard-road-ahead-for-solar-freakin-roadways/| title=Hard Road Ahead for Solar Freakin' Roadways | work=Scientific American | date=July 10, 2014 | accessdate=October 11, 2016}} Sebastian Anthony noted in [[ExtremeTech]] that the cost to replace all roads in the United States with Solar Roadways panels would come to approximately $56 trillion, based on Scott Brusaw's cost estimate of $10,000 for a {{convert|12|x|12|ft|adj=on}} section.{{cite news | url=http://www.extremetech.com/extreme/183130-solar-roadways-passes-1-4-million-in-crowdfunding-just-short-of-the-56-trillion-required-but-not-bad-for-a-crazy-idea | first=Sebastian | last=Anthony | title=Solar Roadways passes $1.4 million in crowdfunding: Just short of the $56 trillion required, but not bad for a crazy idea | work=[[ExtremeTech]] | publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] | date=May 27, 2014 | accessdate=May 15, 2015}} The USDOT announcement of Phase IIB funding in December 2015 mentioned that because the solar cells were still manufactured by hand, they were "very costly to produce". [[Phil Mason]] made a similar argument about cost, adding his doubts about traction on a glass surface.{{cite news |last1=Farrelly |first1=Elizabeth |title=Highways of future, where solar panels change our world |url=https://search.proquest.com/news/docview/1536863134/fulltext/36F5D852A2834544PQ/3?accountid=10226 |accessdate=4 September 2018 |publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=9 June 2014}} ==List of awards and honors== *2010 [[General Electric]] Ecomagination Community Award of $50,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.ecomagination.com/paving-the-solar-roadway-to-success |title=Paving the Solar Roadway to Success |work=Ecomagination.com |first= Michael |last= Parrish DuDell |date=August 8, 2011 |accessdate=June 23, 2014}} *2014 ''[[Popular Science]]''. One of 7 "Best of What's New" Engineering category in the "100 Greatest Innovations of the Year-2014" article.{{cite web |url= http://bestofwhatsnew.popsci.com/solar-roadways |title= Best of What's New: Solar Roadways |work= [[Popular Science]] |first= Aaron |last= Seward |date= 2014 |accessdate= January 6, 2015}} ==See also== {{Portal|Companies|Renewable energy|Energy}} * [[Photovoltaic system]] * [[Asphalt concrete]] * [[SolaRoad]] – the world's first bike path made from solar panels * [[Snowmelt system]] – systems for automatically clearing snow from roads * [[Tourouvre]] - where the first photovoltaic road in the world was under construction in November-December 2016{{cite news|last1=Bourgin|first1=Yohann|title=High Tech. Ségolène Royal lance la première route solaire dans l'Orne|url=http://www.ouest-france.fr/environnement/amenagement-du-territoire/high-tech-segolene-royal-lance-la-premiere-route-solaire-dans-l-orne-4582630|accessdate=November 2, 2016|work=[[Sud-Ouest (newspaper)|Sud-Ouest]]|date=October 25, 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.solarroadways.com/}} * [https://www.transportation.gov/fastlane/new-pavement-system-supported-solar-panels United States Transportation Department's page about them.] {{Photovoltaics}} {{Emerging technologies}} [[Category:Photovoltaics]] [[Category:Vehicle industry]] [[Category:Companies based in Idaho]] [[Category:Emerging technologies]] [[Category:Sandpoint, Idaho]] [[Category:Renewable resource companies established in 2006]]

{{Infobox building |name = Standard Building |image = Standard Building.jpg |image_size = |former_names = Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers' Bank Building, Engineers' Bank Building, Standard Bank Building |location = 1370 Ontario Street [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] 44113 [[United States]] |building_type = Office |floor_count = 21 |start_date = 1923 |completion_date = 1925 |roof = {{convert|85.96 |m|ft|0|abbr=on}} | = |elevator_count = |architect = [[Knox & Elliott]] |owner = Weston, Inc. }}
[[File:From W. 3rd and St. Clair.jpg|thumb|Buildings in Downtown Cleveland, as seen from the intersection of West 3rd Street and St. Clair Avenue]]
[[File:Standard Building detail.jpg|thumb|right|Building detail facing St. Clair Avenue]] '''The Standard Building''', (originally the '''Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers Cooperative National Bank Building''' and later the '''Standard Bank Building'''<ref name="Herrick">{{cite book| last=Herrick| first=Clay| title=Cleveland Landmarks |date=1986 |publisher=Landmarks Publishing Company |pages=156–157}}</ref>), is a [[high-rise]] [[office tower]] located at the southwest corner of Ontario Street and St. Clair Avenue in [[Downtown Cleveland|downtown]] [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]]. Rising to a height of 282 feet (86 meters),<ref>[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=standardbuilding-cleveland-oh-usa Standard Building]. [[Emporis]]. Retrieved on 2007-10-21.</ref> the Standard Building was the second tallest building in Cleveland when it was completed in 1925. Three of its four sides are clad in cream-colored [[Glazed architectural terra-cotta|terra cotta]] with a recurring starburst [[motif (visual arts)|motif]]. The south face, which can be seen from [[Public Square, Cleveland|Public Square]], is unadorned and windowless. It was designed by [[Knox and Elliot]] architects, and was built for $7 million.<ref>{{cite book| last=Rose| first=William Ganson| title=Cleveland: The Making of a City| date=1950| publisher=World Publishing Company| pages=832}}</ref> It was built by the [[Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen]] who owned the building until 2014, when it was sold to Weston, Inc.<ref>{{cite news |first=Michelle |last=Jarboe |title=Standard Building fetches $3.9 million in sale to Weston, Inc. for apartment conversion |url=http://www.cleveland.com/business/index.ssf/2014/07/standard_building_fetches_39_m.html |work=The Plain Dealer |location=Cleveland, Ohio |date=July 1, 2014 |accessdate=January 26, 2017}}</ref>
==History== During the [[Great Depression in the United States|Great Depression]], Standard Bank ran into financial difficulties and was sold by the BLE. It merged with two other Cleveland banks in 1930, forming Standard Trust Bank. This bank subsequently failed in 1931 and its assets were liquidated.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ech.case.edu/ech-cgi/article.pl?id=ST |title=Standard Trust |work=Encyclopedia of Cleveland History |publisher=[[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate=2007-10-20}}</ref> From [[World War II]] through the 1960s, the bank lobby served as an indoctrination center for draftees.<ref name="Herrick" /> In the 1940s the building housed [http://www.case.edu/its/archives/downtown/clevelandcollege.htm Cleveland College], a downtown campus of [[Case Western Reserve University|Western Reserve University]], and was the last building of that campus.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.case.edu/its/archives/Buildings/stabui.htm |title=Standard Building |publisher=[[Case Western Reserve University]] |accessdate=2007-10-20}}</ref>
To the east, across Ontario Street, is the [[Marriott at Key Center]], built on the site of the landmark [[Engineers Building]], which the BLE sold in 1988 for development, moving into the Standard Building.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ble.org/pr/history/page5h.html |title=BLE History |publisher=[[Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen]] |accessdate=2007-10-20}}</ref> To the north, across St. Clair Avenue, is the [[Cuyahoga County Justice Center]]. The [[Old Stone Church (Cleveland)|Old Stone Church]] abuts its south side.
Currently it is the 21st highest building in Cleveland. It was designated a Cleveland Landmark in 1979.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://planning.city.cleveland.oh.us/landmark/listDetail.php?identity=228 |title=Standard Building |work=Cleveland Designated Landmarks |publisher=[[Cleveland]] Landmarks Commission |accessdate=2007-10-20}}</ref> In 2007, the boundary<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ohiohistory.org/about/pr/040307a.html |title=State Board Recommends Seven Ohio Nominations To The National Register Of Historic Places |date=April 3, 2007 |publisher=[[Ohio Historical Society]] |accessdate=2007-10-20}}</ref> of the [[Euclid Avenue Historic District (Cleveland, Ohio)|Euclid Avenue Historic District]] was increased<ref>{{NRISref|version=2010a}}</ref> to include the building, among other structures. In 2014, it was purchased by Weston, Inc. for $3.9 million, and {{as of|January 2017|lc=yes}} is being converted into an apartment building.<ref>{{cite news |first=Michelle |last=Jarboe |title=Standard Building near Public Square will become apartments, after sale to Weston, Inc. |url=http://www.cleveland.com/business/index.ssf/2014/06/standard_building_near_public.html |work=The Plain Dealer |location=Cleveland, Ohio |date=June 30, 2014 |accessdate=January 26, 2017}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in Cleveland]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== {{commons category|Standard Building}} *[http://www.thestandardcle.com/ The Standard Building]
{{coord|41|30|2.98|N|81|41|43.47|W|type:landmark_region:US-OH|display=title}}
[[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Cleveland]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1925]] [[Category:Downtown Cleveland]]

{{Infobox person | name = Hsu-Tien Tung | image = 2016TGS Opening Tsu-Hsien Tung.jpg | image_size = 180px | caption = Tung at 2016 [[:zh:台北國際電玩展|Taipei Game Show]] | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|6|25|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Ruisui, Hualien|Ruisui]], [[Hualien County]], [[Taiwan]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | alma mater = [[National Taipei University of Technology]] | employer = | occupation = Businessman | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = }} '''Hsu-Tien Tung''' (born c. 1960)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=113921860&capId=44006094&previousCapId=7689790&previousTitle=SINOPAC%20FINANCIAL%20HOLDINGS|publisher=Blomberg|title=T. H. Tung}}</ref> is a [[Taiwan]]ese businessman and philanthropist. He is a co-founder of [[Asus]] and its former vice chairman. He serves as the chairman of [[Pegatron]].
==Early life== T.H. Tung was born circa 1960 and grew up in [[Ruisui, Hualien|Ruisui]], [[Hualien County]], [[Taiwan]].<ref name="commonwealthchairman">{{cite news|last1=Huang|first1=Dennis|title=Pegatron Chairman T. H. Tung: Giving the World an Unending Dividend|url=http://english.cw.com.tw/article.do?action=show&id=13671|accessdate=2 February 2016|work=CommonWealth Magazine|date=5 July 2012}}</ref> His father was a watchmaker.<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/> He grew up in the countryside, without a television set, and played [[Little League Baseball]].<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/> He became an avid reader, and was influenced by the works of [[Yang Mu]] and [[Hu Shih]].<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/>
Tung received a master's degree in computer and communication engineering from the [[National Taipei University of Technology]].<ref name="pegatronboard">{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=http://www.pegatroncorp.com/investorRelations/directors.php|website=Pegatron|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref> While he was at university, he regularly skipped class to read independently instead, often reading censored books.<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/> He was also the editor-in-chief of the campus newspaper.<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/>
==Career== Tung started his career at [[Acer Inc.]].<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/> T.H. Tung co-founded [[Asus]] in 1989.<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/> He served as its vice chairman.<ref name="pegatronboard"/> He became the majority shareholder of [[Eslite Bookstore]].<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/>
Tung serves as the chairman of [[Pegatron]].<ref name="pegatronboard"/> Additionally, he serves as the chairman of [[Kinsus]] and [[Lumens (company)|Lumens]].<ref name="pegatronboard"/>
==Philanthropy== According to ''[[CommonWealth Magazine]]'', "He has sponsored countless artistic and cultural events and financed historical research on late presidents [[Chiang Kai-shek]] and [[Chiang Ching-kuo]] and documentaries on the careers of Taiwanese writers."<ref name="commonwealthchairman"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Tung, T.H.}} [[Category:1960s births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Hualien County]] [[Category:Taiwanese businesspeople]] [[Category:Taiwanese company founders]] [[Category:Taiwanese philanthropists]] [[Category:Asus]] [[Category:20th-century Taiwanese businesspeople]] [[Category:21st-century Taiwanese businesspeople]]
{{Taiwan-stub}}

revision.comment: The [[E 66 road (United Arab Emirates)|road]] from [[Al Ain]] to [[Dubai]] was renamed in his honor
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=March 2016}} {{More footnotes|date=March 2016}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{arabic name|Al Nahyan}} {{Infobox Mayor |honorific-prefix = HH Sheikh |name = Tahnoun bin Mohammed Al Nahyan |honorific-suffix = |image = |imagesize = 250px |order = |office = Ruler's Representative in the Eastern Region |term_start = 1971 |term_end = |monarch = [[Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan]]
[[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] |predecessor = [[Khalifa bin Zayed Al Nahyan]] |successor = |order2 = |office2 = Deputy Chairman of the Executive Council of Abu Dhabi |term_start2 = 1977 ||monarch2 = [[Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan]] |birth_place = [[Al Ain]] |nationality = [[Emiratis|Emirati]] |spouse = }} '''Tahnoun bin Mohammed Al Nahyan''' ({{lang-ar|'''طحنون بن محمد آل نهيان'''|ṭaḥnūn bin muḥammad ʾāl nahyān}}) is the Ruler's Representative of the [[Al-Ain Region, Abu Dhabi|Eastern Region]] of the [[Emirate of Abu Dhabi]], the [[United Arab Emirates]]. He was previously deputy chairman of the [[Executive Council of Abu Dhabi]], chairman of the [[Abu Dhabi National Oil Company]] and deputy chairman of the [[Supreme Petroleum Council]].[http://www.abudhabi.ae/egovPoolPortal_WAR/appmanager/ADeGP/Citizen?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=P2401445751200487742914&lang=en Government Structure and System][http://erd.ae/ Ruler's Representative Court Eastern Region][http://erd.ae/en/portal/C55827FB-8FAE-496D-82E4-BFCB990BA5A3.aspx Rulers Reperesentative court] In November 2018, the [[E 66 road (United Arab Emirates)|road]] from [[Al Ain]] to [[Dubai]] was renamed in his honor.{{cite news |work=[[Emirates News Agency|WAM]] |title=Dubai-Al Ain Road renamed |publisher=[[Gulf News]] |url=https://gulfnews.com/news/uae/general/dubai-crime-and-accidents-down-in-al-faqa-1.1319434 |location=[[Al Ain]] |date=2018-11-02 |access-date=2018-11-04}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.abudhabi.ae/egovPoolPortal_WAR/appmanager/ADeGP/Citizen?_nfpb=true&_pageLabel=P2401445751200487742914&lang=en Government Structure and System] *[http://erd.ae/ Ruler's Representative Court Eastern Region] *[http://erd.ae/en/portal/C55827FB-8FAE-496D-82E4-BFCB990BA5A3.aspx Rulers Reperesentative court] {{DEFAULTSORT:Nahyan, Tahnoun Bin Mohammed}} [[Category:Emirati royalty]] [[Category:Emirati businesspeople]] [[Category:House of Al Nahyan|Tahnoun bin Mohammed Al Nahyan]] [[Category:People from Abu Dhabi]] [[Category:Tufts University alumni]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] {{UnitedArabEmirates-bio-stub}} {{MEast-royal-stub}}

{{Japanese name|Miyahara}} {{nihongo|'''Takashi Miyahara'''|宮原 巍|Miyahara Takashi|born 1934 in [[Nagano Prefecture|Nagano]], [[Japan]]}} is a [[Nepal]]ese tourism entrepreneur and politician. Miyahara has lived over 40 years in Nepal.<ref name="time">[http://www.nepalitimes.com/issue/343/FromtheNepaliPress/13408 National Development Party - Nepali Times<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Miyahara holds a bachelor's degree in Chemical and Mechanical Engineering from [[Nihon University]], [[Tokyo]]. When he moved to Nepal, he began working for the Department of Cottage Industry of Nepal.<ref name="pers">[http://www.nepalnews.com.np/contents/englishmonthly/businessage/2003/jun/personality.htm Personality<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Miyahara is the chairman of the boards of Himalaya Hotel in [[Kathmandu]] and Trans Himalaya Treks.<ref>[http://www.fncci.org/members/page1.php?op=pageload&file=search_result&type=am&am_catid=16 Federation of Nepalese Chambers of Commerce and Industry [FNCCI]<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Miyahara founded Trans Himalaya Tours in 1968 and a Japanese sister company, Himalaya Kanko Kitatsu, in 1969. The following year, he founded Trans Himalayan Trekking.<ref name="pers"/>
In 2006, Miyahara founded the [[Nepal Rastriya Bikas Party]]. He became a citizen of Nepal in order to be able to work politically.<ref name="time"/> At the 2008 election of the Nepalese Constituent Assembly, none of the candidates won the seat.

{{About|the 1960 Hollywood film|the 1996 French film|The Apartment (1996 film)}} {{other uses|Apartment (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox film | name = The Apartment | image = Apartment 60.jpg | caption = Original film poster | director = [[Billy Wilder]] | producer = Billy Wilder | writer = {{unbulleted list|Billy Wilder|[[I. A. L. Diamond]]}} | starring = {{unbulleted list|[[Jack Lemmon]]|[[Shirley MacLaine]]|[[Fred MacMurray]]|[[Jack Kruschen]]}} | music = [[Adolph Deutsch]] | cinematography = [[Joseph LaShelle]] | editing = [[Daniel Mandell]] | studio = [[The Mirisch Company]] | distributor = [[United Artists]] | released = {{Film date|1960|6|15}} | runtime = 125 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $3 million | gross = $24.6 million[http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1960/0APAR.php Box Office Information for ''The Apartment.''] The Numbers. Retrieved April 13, 2012. }} '''''The Apartment''''' is a 1960 American [[romantic comedy]] film, produced and directed by [[Billy Wilder]] from a screenplay he co-wrote with [[I. A. L. Diamond]], starring [[Jack Lemmon]] and [[Shirley MacLaine]]. The supporting cast are [[Fred MacMurray]], [[Ray Walston]], [[Jack Kruschen]], [[David Lewis (American actor)|David Lewis]], [[Willard Waterman]], [[David White (actor)|David White]], [[Hope Holiday]], and [[Edie Adams]]. The story follows C. C. “Bud” Baxter (Lemmon), an [[insurance]] clerk who in the hope of gaining promotion, permits four more senior men to occupy his [[Upper West Side]] apartment to conduct extramarital affairs. Bud is attracted to the [[elevator operator]], Fran Kubelik (MacLaine) who in turn is having an affair with Bud's immediate boss, Sheldrake (MacMurray). ''The Apartment'' was distributed by [[United Artists]] to favorable reviews and commercial success, despite controversy owing to its subject matter. At the [[33rd Academy Awards]], ''The Apartment'' was nominated for ten awards and won five, including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]], and [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Screenplay]]. Lemmon and MacLaine were Oscar-nominated and won [[Golden Globe Award|Golden Globe Awards]] for their performances in the film. It provided the basis for ''[[Promises, Promises (musical)|Promises, Promises]]'', a 1968 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] [[musical theatre|musical]] by [[Burt Bacharach]], [[Hal David]], and [[Neil Simon]]. In the years since its release, ''The Apartment'' has come to be regarded as one of the greatest films ever made, appearing in lists by the [[American Film Institute]] and ''[[Sight and Sound]]'' magazine, and being selected by the [[United States Library of Congress]] for preservation in the [[National Film Registry]]. ==Plot== C. C. "Bud" Baxter ([[Jack Lemmon]]) is a lonely office drudge at a national insurance corporation in a high-rise building in [[New York City]]. In order to climb the corporate ladder, Bud allows four company managers to take turns borrowing his [[Upper West Side]] apartment for their various extramarital liaisons, which are so noisy that his neighbors assume that Bud is a playboy bringing home a different woman every night. The four managers (played by [[Ray Walston]], [[David Lewis (American actor)|David Lewis]], [[Willard Waterman]], and [[David White (actor)|David White]]) write glowing reports about Bud, who hopes for a promotion from the personnel director, Jeff D. Sheldrake ([[Fred MacMurray]]). Sheldrake does promote Bud, but he knows why they were so enthusiastic and demands exclusive privileges to borrow the apartment himself, starting that same night. As compensation for such short notice, he gives Baxter two tickets to ''[[The Music Man]]''. After work, Bud catches Fran Kubelik ([[Shirley MacLaine]]), an [[elevator operator]] he has had his eye on, and asks her to go to the musical with him. She accepts, but first has to meet a former fling. He is Sheldrake, who convinces her that he is about to divorce his wife for her. They go to Bud's apartment as Bud waits forlornly outside the theater. Later, at the company's raucous Christmas party, Sheldrake's secretary Miss Olsen ([[Edie Adams]]) drunkenly tells Fran that Fran is one of many female employees Sheldrake has seduced into affairs with the promise of divorcing his wife, including Miss Olsen herself. At Bud's apartment, Fran confronts Sheldrake, upset with herself for believing his lies. Sheldrake maintains that he genuinely loves her, but then leaves to return to his suburban family as usual. Meanwhile, Bud accidentally learns about Sheldrake and Fran. Heartbroken, he lets himself be picked up by a woman ([[Hope Holiday]]) at a local bar. When they arrive at his apartment, he is shocked to find Fran in his bed, fully clothed and unconscious from an intentional overdose of his sleeping pills. He sends his pick-up away and enlists the help of his neighbor, Dr. Dreyfuss ([[Jack Kruschen]]), to revive Fran without notifying the authorities. To protect his job, Bud takes advantage of his playboy reputation, letting Dreyfuss believe Fran had attempted suicide after a lovers' quarrel with him. Fran spends two days recuperating there, while Bud tries entertaining and distracting her from any suicidal thoughts. He tells her he once attempted suicide himself. They begin playing [[gin rummy]]. Bud dissuades her from phoning her family until her head is clear. During this period one of the executives arrives with a woman; Bud sends them away, but the man sees Fran. Then Fran's brother-in-law Karl Matuschka ([[Johnny Seven (actor)|Johnny Seven]]) comes to the office looking for her. Resenting Bud for denying them access to his apartment, the executives direct Karl there. When Bud again takes responsibility for Fran's actions, Karl punches him. Fran kisses Bud for not revealing her affair with Sheldrake and, sensing that she now cares for him, Bud smiles and says it "didn't hurt a bit." Sheldrake rewards Bud with a further promotion, and fires Miss Olsen for what she told Fran. However, Miss Olsen retaliates by telling Sheldrake's wife, who promptly throws him out. Sheldrake moves into a room at his athletic club, but now figures that he can string Fran along while he enjoys his newfound bachelorhood. But when Sheldrake asks Bud for the key to the apartment, Bud refuses, quitting the firm. That night at a [[New Year's Eve]] party, Sheldrake indignantly tells Fran about this. She finally realizes that Bud is the man who truly loves her. She runs to his apartment, but at the door, she hears a loud noise like a gunshot. Fearing he has attempted suicide again, Fran pounds on the door until Bud opens it, holding an overflowing bottle of champagne which was the source of the noise. Bud has been packing, planning to find a new job and a new home, but is surprised and delighted to see her. Fran insists on resuming their gin rummy game, telling Bud that she is now free as well. He declares his love for her, and she replies lovingly, "Shut up and deal." ==Cast== [[Image:The apartment trailer 1.JPG|240px|thumb|right|Calvin Clifford "Bud" Baxter ([[Jack Lemmon]]) and Fran Kubelik ([[Shirley MacLaine]]), in a still from the film's final scene: "Shut up and deal."]] * [[Jack Lemmon]] as Calvin Clifford (C. C.) "Bud" Baxter * [[Shirley MacLaine]] as Fran Kubelik * [[Fred MacMurray]] as Jeff D. Sheldrake, personnel manager, Baxter's boss and apartment user * [[Ray Walston]] as Joe Dobisch, office manager and Baxter apartment user * [[Jack Kruschen]] as Dr. Dreyfuss, Baxter's neighbor * [[David Lewis (American actor)|David Lewis]] as Al Kirkeby, manager and Baxter apartment user * [[Edie Adams]] as Miss Olsen * [[Hope Holiday]] as Mrs. Margie MacDougall * [[Joan Shawlee]] as Sylvia * [[Naomi Stevens]] as Mrs. Mildred Dreyfuss * [[Johnny Seven (actor)|Johnny Seven]] as Karl Matuschka (Fran's cab driving brother-in-law) * [[Joyce Jameson]] as the blonde in the bar * [[Hal Smith (actor)|Hal Smith]] as [[Santa Claus]] in the bar * [[Willard Waterman]] as Mr. Vanderhoff, manager and Baxter apartment user * [[David White (actor)|David White]] as Mr. Eichelberger, manager and Baxter apartment user ==Production== [[File:The apartment trailer jack lemmon.JPG|thumb|left|The apartment trailer jack lemmon|thumb|right|[[Jack Lemmon]] in a still from the film's trailer. ''The Apartment'' marked his second collaboration with [[Billy Wilder]] after ''[[Some Like It Hot]]''.]] Immediately following the success of ''[[Some Like It Hot]]'', Billy Wilder and I.A.L. Diamond wished to make another film with Jack Lemmon. Wilder had originally planned to cast [[Paul Douglas (actor)|Paul Douglas]] as Jeff Sheldrake; however, after he died unexpectedly, Fred MacMurray was cast. The initial concept for the film came from ''[[Brief Encounter]]'' by [[Noël Coward]], in which Celia Johnson has an affair with Trevor Howard in his friend's apartment. However, due to the [[Hays Production Code]], Wilder was unable to make a film about adultery in the 1940s. Wilder and Diamond also based the film partially on a Hollywood scandal in which high-powered agent [[Jennings Lang]] was shot by producer [[Walter Wanger]] for having an affair with Wanger's wife, actress [[Joan Bennett]]. During the affair, Lang used a low-level employee's apartment.Billy Wilder Interviews: [[Conversations with Filmmakers Series]] Another element of the plot was based on the experience of one of Diamond's friends, who returned home after breaking up with his girlfriend to find that she had committed suicide in his bed. Although Wilder generally required his actors to adhere exactly to the script, he allowed Jack Lemmon to improvise in two scenes: In one scene he squirts a bottle of nasal spray across the room, and in another, he sings while cooking spaghetti (which he strains through the grid of a tennis racket). In another scene, where Lemmon was supposed to mime being punched, he failed to move correctly, and was accidentally knocked down. Wilder chose to use the shot of the genuine punch in the film. Lemmon also caught a cold when one scene on a park bench was filmed in sub-zero weather. Art director [[Alexandre Trauner]] used forced perspective to create the set of a large insurance company office. The set appeared to be a very long room full of desks and workers; however, successively smaller people and desks were placed to the back of the room, ending up with children. He designed the set of Baxter's apartment to appear smaller and shabbier than the spacious apartments that usually appeared in films of the day. He used items from thrift stores and even some of Wilder's own furniture for the set.Chandler, Charlotte. ''Nobody's perfect: Billy Wilder : a personal biography''. The film's title theme, written by [[Charles Williams (composer)|Charles Williams]] and originally titled "Jealous Lover", was first heard in the 1949 film ''[[The Romantic Age]]''.[https://web.archive.org/web/20080224234735/http://www.guildmusic.com/light/catalogue/5107.htm 5107 Charles Williams & The Queen's Hall Light Orchestra at GuildMusic.com]. Archived from [http://www.guildmusic.com/light/catalogue/5135.htm Charles Williams at GuildMusic.com]Eldridge, Jeff. [http://www.filmscoremonthly.com/notes/apartment.html FSM: The Apartment] FilmScoreMonthly.com[http://www.kritzerland.com/apt.htm Adoph Deutsch's "The Apartment" w/ Andre Previn's "The Fortune Cookie"] Kritzerland.com A recording by [[Ferrante & Teicher]], released as "The Theme from ''The Apartment''", reached #10 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart later in 1960. ==Reception== In 1960, the film made double its $3 million budget at the U.S. box office.{{cite news|last1=Fuller|first1=Graham|title=An Undervalued American Classic|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/18/movies/film-an-undervalued-american-classic.html?pagewanted=1|accessdate=2 September 2017|work=The New York Times|date=June 18, 2000}}{{cite web|title=The Apartment(1960)|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title/16634/The-Apartment/articles.html|website=Turner Classic Movies|accessdate=2 September 2017}}Tino Balio, ''United Artists: The Company That Changed the Film Industry'', University of Wisconsin Press, 1987 p. 170 Critics were split on ''The Apartment''.{{cite book|last1=Phillips|first1=Gene D.|title=Some Like It Wilder: The Life and Controversial Films of Billy Wilder|date=2010|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|location=Lexington, Kentucky, USA|isbn=978-0-8131-2570-1}} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' and ''[[Newsweek]]'' praised it, as did ''[[The New York Times]]'' film critic [[Bosley Crowther]], who called the film "gleeful, tender, and even sentimental" and Wilder's direction "ingenious".{{cite news|last1=Crowther|first1=Bosley|title=Busy 'Apartment':Jack Lemmon Scores in Billy Wilder Film|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movie/review?res=9C01EFD91638EF32A25755C1A9609C946191D6CF&mcubz=0|accessdate=2 September 2017|work=The New York Times|date=June 16, 1960}} ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' critic [[Dwight Macdonald]] gave the film a poor review, calling it "a paradigm of corny avantgardism".{{cite book|last1=Horrocks|first1=Roger|title=Len Lye: A Biography|date=2001|publisher=Auckland University Press,|location=Auckland, New Zealand|isbn=1-86940-247-2|page=257|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YUrlAQAAQBAJ&dq=Dwight+Macdonald+%22the+apartment%22+esquire&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=2 September 2017|ref=Horrocks}} Others took issue with the film's controversial depictions of infidelity and adultery, with critic [[Hollis Alpert]] of the ''[[Saturday Review (US magazine)|Saturday Review]]'' dismissing it as "a dirty fairy tale". According to Fred MacMurray, after the film's release, he was accosted by women in the street who berated him for making a "dirty filthy movie", one of them hitting him with her purse. [[File:Gloria Swanson & Billy Wilder - ca. 1950.JPG|thumb|right|[[Billy Wilder]] (seen here with [[Gloria Swanson]]) won three [[Academy Award|Academy Awards]] for his work as a director, producer and writer on the film.]] In 2001, ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' film critic [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film four stars out of four, and added it to his [[The Great Movies|Great Movies]] list.{{cite news |title=Great Movie: The Apartment |last=Ebert |first=Roger |date=July 22, 2001 |url=http://www.rogerebert.com/reviews/great-movie-the-apartment-1960 }} As of 2017 the film had a 93% "Certified Fresh" rating on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 59 reviews with an average rating of 8.5/10; the site's consensus states that "Director Billy Wilder's customary cynicism is leavened here by tender humor, romance, and genuine pathos."{{cite web|title=The Apartment (1960)|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1001115_apartment|website=Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate=2 September 2017}} ===33rd Academy Awards (Oscars) - 1960=== ''The Apartment'' received 10 [[33rd Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominations, and won 5 Academy Awards.{{Cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1961 |title=The 33rd Academy Awards (1960) Nominees and Winners |accessdate=2011-08-22|work=oscars.org}}{{cite web |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/2667/The-Apartment/awards |title=NY Times: The Apartment |accessdate=2008-12-23|work=NY Times}} {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Award !! Result !! Nominee |- | [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] | {{won}} | [[Billy Wilder]] |- | [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] | {{won}} | Billy Wilder |- | [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Writing (Original Screenplay)]] | {{won}} | [[I. A. L. Diamond]]
Billy Wilder |- | [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] | {{nom}} | [[Jack Lemmon]] |- | [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] | {{nom}} | [[Shirley MacLaine]] |- | [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]] | {{nom}} | [[Jack Kruschen]] |- | [[Academy Award for Best Cinematography|Best Cinematography (Black-and-White)]] | {{nom}} | [[Joseph LaShelle]] |- | [[Academy Award for Best Film Editing|Best Film Editing]] | {{won}} | [[Daniel Mandell]] |- | [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Best Art Direction-Set Decoration, Black-and-White]] | {{won}} | [[Alexandre Trauner]]
[[Edward G. Boyle]] |- | [[Academy Award for Best Sound Mixing|Best Sound]] | {{nom}} | [[Gordon E. Sawyer]] |} Although Jack Lemmon did not win the Oscar, [[Kevin Spacey]] dedicated his Oscar for ''[[American Beauty (1999 film)|American Beauty]]'' (1999) to Lemmon's performance. According to the behind-the-scenes feature on the ''American Beauty'' DVD, the film's director, [[Sam Mendes]], had watched ''The Apartment'' (among other classic American films) as inspiration in preparation for shooting his film. Within a few years after ''The Apartment'''s release, the routine use of [[black-and-white]] film in Hollywood had ended. As of 2014, only two black-and-white movies have won the Academy Award for Best Picture after ''The Apartment'' did: ''[[Schindler's List]]'' (1993) and ''[[The Artist (film)|The Artist]]'' (2011). ===Other awards and honors=== ''The Apartment'' also won the [[BAFTA Award for Best Film from any Source]] and Lemmon and MacLaine both won a [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] and a [[Golden Globe]] each for their performances. In 1994, ''The Apartment'' was deemed "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant" by the United States [[Library of Congress]] and selected for preservation in the [[National Film Registry]]. In 2002, a poll of film directors conducted by ''[[Sight and Sound]]'' magazine listed the film as the 14th greatest film of all time (tied with ''[[La Dolce Vita]]'').[https://www.bfi.org.uk/sightandsound/topten/poll/directors-long.html BFI | Sight & Sound | Top Ten Poll 2002 - The rest of the directors' list] In 2006, ''Premiere'' voted this film as one of "The 50 Greatest Comedies Of All Time". [[American Film Institute]] *[[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies]] (#93),{{cite web |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies |url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/movies100.pdf |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |accessdate=2016-07-17}} *[[AFI's 100 Years...100 Laughs]] (#20),{{cite web |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Laughs |url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/laughs100.pdf |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |accessdate=2016-07-17}} *[[AFI's 100 Years...100 Passions]] (#62),{{cite web |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Passions |url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/passions100.pdf |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |accessdate=2016-07-17}} *[[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition)]] (#80).{{cite web |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Movies (10th Anniversary Edition) |url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/100Movies.pdf |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |accessdate=2016-07-17}} *[[AFI's 100 Years...100 Movie Quotes]]: ** Fran Kubelik: "Shut up, and deal." - Nominated ==Quotes== J. D. Sheldrake: "But when you've been married to a woman for twelve years, you don't just sit down at the breakfast table and say 'Pass the sugar and I want a divorce.'" ==See also== * [[List of American films of 1960]] * ''[[Life in a... revision.text:
The '''Tun Abdul Razak Research Centre''', originally known as the '''British Rubber Producers' Research Association''', carries out research into rubber and is funded by the Malaysian government. ==Early years: as the British Rubber Producers Research Association: 1938 to 1957== The '''British Rubber Producers Research Association''' was formed as a scientific research organization in 1938 'to understand rubber and in pursuit of this aim to mount a programme of fundamental research', since at that time the technology was almost entirely empirical.Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society (1999) vol 45 pp 185-194 It carried out fundamental work on [[rubber]], which included the more general [[polymer science]] and the physics and mathematics of [[rheology]] and in addition contributed to early work on electronic computers. Prominent in the push for greater rubber research and the establishment of the association was [[Sir Eric Miller (rubber industrialist)|Sir Eric Miller]], who became chairman of the BRPRA.Obituary: Sir Eric Miller, Prominent figure in the rubber industry, The Times 12 July 1958 In 1939 it obtained its first premises in [[Welwyn Garden City]]. It was largely funded by a levy on British-owned companies with plantations in [[British Malaya|Malaya]] and [[Ceylon]]. Its Director of Research from 1938 to 1947 was [[John Wilson (industrial chemist)|John Wilson]]. His:
unconventional qualities, combined as they were with super-abundant energy and remarkable visionary zeal, proved their value as he built up the BRPRA in a difficult period and made it a world-renowned research unit within a decade or so. He chose his staff on trusted recommendation or by intuition, and thus assembled a group which radically advanced the science of rubber [at the BRRA], sowed seeds that have produced substantial commercial fruits, and which was to become the source of distinguished alumni in high academic and industrial posts in this country, America and elsewhere ... [Wilson's] stimulating ebullience, his concern with work not red tape, and his abiding principle to support and fight to the limit for his staff outside the laboratories (however much he might assail them inside) engendered immense loyalty and a wonderful team spirit.The Times, Obituaries 24 September 1976
He resigned to become Director of the newly formed [[British Rayon Research Association]]. A number of staff followed him, including [[LRG Treloar]].Autobiographical note, Collected papers of R.S. Rivlin, Volume 1 By Ronald S. Rivlin, G. I. Barenblatt, Daniel D. Joseph ==After de-colonisation and Malaysian independence== In 1957, Malaya achieved independence from British Rule and the name was changed to the '''Natural Rubber Producers' Research Association'''. By the start of the 1970s, its research priorities included new methods of vulcanisation, injection moulding of rubber and developing anti-oxidants to protect against the deterioration of rubber.''Scientists seek to combine the best of old and new'', The Times, 25 January 1981, page 24 During this period, the Association produced work on the engineering uses of rubber. This, by 1964, led to the development of rubber mounts for buildings to protect against vibrations. eventually this led to the use of mounts to protect against earthquakes.[http://www.tarrc.co.uk/pages/cohistory.htm www.tarrc.co.uk] TARRC Company History In later years, this work was extended to smaller buildings. In 1973 it was changed to the '''Malaysian Rubber Producers' Research Association'''. In 1974 the research base was relocated to Brickendonbury, [[Hertfordshire]] in a mansion which had been used for the children's television series [[Catweazle]].[http://www.tarrc.co.uk/pages/brickhistory.htm www.tarrc.co.uk] Brickendonbury History In 1997 it was named the Tun Abdul Razak Laboratory by the Malaysian Prime Minister [[Tun Hussein Onn]]. Later research included work on blends of rubber and synthetics, such as nitrile, ethylene propylene rubber and Epoxidised natural rubber. The centre also worked on the performance of tyre retread compounds, showing that natural rubber-rich tyres could perform nearly as well as synthetic tyres in durability, but were more fuel efficient as they had lower rolling resistance. The centre also developed an entirely new material, thermoplastic epoxidized natural rubber. This has excellent oil-resistance and heat resistance.Thermoplastic epoxidized natural rubber - a new TPE for the 21st Century, Patel, J.; Tinker, A.J. 1997 ==Tun Abdul Razak Research Centre== In 1996, it became the Tun Abdul Razak Research Centre, a wholly owned company of the [[Malaysian Rubber Board]]. The centre has various research focusses including advanced materials, products, engineering and Biotechnology. Whilst the main purpose is to support the Malaysian rubber industry, the commercial division, Rubber Consultants offers a variety of testing and other services. These include compounding, physical testing, engineering design tyre testing and analytical services. ==Researchers== ===Notable people who worked at the BRPRA=== *[[Edgar Andrews]] *[[Andrew Donald Booth]] *[[Leslie Clifford Bateman]] *[[Alan Neville Gent]] *[[Karl A. Grosch]] *[[Walter Haworth|Norman Haworth]] *[[Graham Lake (cricketer)|Graham J. Lake]] * [[William Moffitt]]Prof William Moffit, Obituaries, by [[Charles Coulson|Professor Coulson]], The Times, 30 December 1958 page 8 *[[Leonard Mullins]] *[[Ronald Rivlin]] *[[Alan D. Roberts (physicist)|Alan D. Roberts]] * [[Adolf Schallamach]] * [[Alan G. Thomas (scientist)|Alan G. Thomas]] *[[LRG Treloar]] *[[John Wilson (industrial chemist)]], Director of Research 1938-47The Times obituary, 15 September 1976 ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:British research associations]] [[Category:East Hertfordshire District]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1938]] [[Category:Research institutes in Hertfordshire]] [[Category:Rubber industry]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox politician |name = Victoria Carter |honorific-suffix = {{post-nominals|country=NZL|ONZM|size=100%}} |image = |caption = |birth_place = [[England]] |alma_mater = [[University of Auckland]] |occupation = [[Company director]] and [[Businesswoman]] |nationality=[[New Zealand]]}}
'''Victoria Mary Carter''' {{post-nominals|country=NZL|ONZM|size=85%}} is a former [[New Zealand]] politician. She is now a professional [[company director]] and [[businesswoman]].
==Early life== Carter, born in [[England]], came to New Zealand with her mother, journalist [[Valerie Davies (journalist)|Valerie Davies]]. Her stepfather was journalist, [[Pat Booth (journalist)|Pat Booth]].<ref>[http://www.womensweekly.co.nz/latest/real-life/interview-former-weekly-columnist-valerie-davies-12412 Interview: Former Weekly Columnist Valerie Davies], Women’s Weekly.</ref>
==Education and early career== Carter holds a law degree from the [[University of Auckland]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.alumni.auckland.ac.nz/en/news/news-2016/01/25/new-years-honours-for-alumni-and-staff.html|title=New Years Honours for alumni and staff - The University of Auckland|last=|first=|date=|website=www.alumni.auckland.ac.nz|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> and has a varied background in public relations, marketing, and governance. Carter has served on the boards of Kidicorp, Turner’s Auctions, New Zealand Thoroughbred Racing, [[Auckland Racing Club]], and [[JUCY|JUCY group]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nzracing.co.nz/NZTR/About/Press-Release/12779/Victoria-Carter-appointed-to-the-NZTR-Board-.aspx|title=Press Release / About / NZTR / NZRacing|last=|first=|date=|website=July 2016|publisher=|access-date=22 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10461595|title=End of an era for our kindys|last=Chateau|first=Carroll du|date=2007-08-25|work=|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777|access-date=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globalwomen.org.nz/our-people/our-members/show/116/victoria-carter|title=Our Members |last=|first=|date= |website=www.globalwomen.org.nz|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> She was extensively involved with the Auckland Kindergarten Association from 1995 to 2005, as Chair (4 years), Deputy-Chair (3 years), and Councillor (3 years), ending up as the President of the Association.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=215351|title=Serious child's play|last=|first=|date=2001-09-07|work=|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777|access-date=|via=}}</ref><ref>[http://women.govt.nz/inspiring-women/10-questions-victoria-carter 10 Questions: Victoria Carter], Ministry for Women.</ref>
== Political career ==
Carter was elected as an [[Auckland City]] Councillor in 1998 for the [[Hobson (New Zealand electorate)|Hobson]] ward.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/women-of-influence/73591257/women-of-influence-2015-finalists-arts-and-culture|title=Women of Influence finalists: Arts and Culture|last=|first=|date=|website=Stuff|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Carter was the first independent trustee to be elected to the [[Auckland Energy Consumer Trust]] in 1997, but had to resign from this position when elected to [[Auckland City Council]].<ref>[http://www.kirstenmatthew.com/pdf/profiles/QueenVictoria.pdf Queen Victoria], Metro Magazine NZ</ref>
She served as Chair of City Attractions at Auckland City Council and led the public private partnership that saw the indoor arena at Quay Street built.<ref>[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=138113 Dialogue: Downtown indoor arena the best plan for region], NZ Herald.</ref> Carter also restarted the [[Auckland Arts Festival]] which she chaired until June 2015.<ref>[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=2998173 Brian Rudman: Thanks to Victoria Carter, our festival is on again], NZ Herald.</ref>
==Later career== Carter left politics in 2003 to pursue business opportunities, co-founding [[Cityhop]], New Zealand’s first car sharing company with [[JUCY|JUCY Group]] led by brothers Tim and Dan Alpe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cityhop.co.nz/media/NBRarticle.pdf|title=Rent cars by the hour in Auckland, National Business Review|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|via=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11606072 Victoria Carter: Car-share would get city moving], NZ Herald.</ref>
== Awards == In 2013 Carter was named in the inaugural Forty Over 40 list acknowledging women who are disrupting and reinventing, and was the only Australasian selected.<ref>[http://fortyover40.com/2013-honorees/ Forty Over 40 2013 Honorees], Forty Over 40.</ref> She was a finalist in the arts category of the Women of Influence awards in 2013 and 2014.<ref>[http://www.aucklandfestival.co.nz/news/victoria-carter-finalist-for-2014-women-of-influence-awards/ Victoria Carter: Women of Influence Finalist], Auckland Arts Festival.</ref>
In the [[2016 New Year Honours]] Carter was appointed an [[New Zealand Order of Merit|Officer of the New Zealand Order of Merit]] for service to arts, business, and the community.<ref>[http://www.stuff.co.nz/auckland/75655104/new-years-honour-for-multitasking-victoria-carter New Years honour for multi-tasking Victoria Carter], Stuff NZ.</ref>
